awd_titl_txt: The Development of Relational Processing in Infancy
awd_abstract_narration:
Analogical ability is the ability to make relational comparisons between objects, events, or ideas, and to see common relational patterns across them.  It is a cornerstone of higher reasoning ability, and is essential for learning mathematics and science.  This project  investigates the nature of this ability and how it develops in infants, tracing its development over the first year of life.  Delineating the conditions that promote relational learning in young infants, will lead to insights into how best to promote relational learning in children and in adults who show lags in abstract learning. One result of the proposed studies will be a set of methods and tools that can be used by teachers and caregivers to support relational learning. For example, this research can serve as a springboard for developing targeted interventions for young children diagnosed with language delay, as well as those diagnosed with autistic spectrum disorders.  Another result will be a better understanding of how to build artificial intelligence systems that learn more like people, with far less data than today's systems require.

The starting point for this proposal is a recent demonstration that 7- and 9-month-old infants can form abstract same and different relations, and apply them to new objects.  The preliminary studies suggest that even 3-month-old infants are capable of relational learning; however, they are highly vulnerable to distraction by the interestingness of the objects in the pairs.  The new research will use four series of experiments to trace infants' ability to learn abstract relations.  The first will examine the processes that promote relational learning in 3-month-olds.  The second will investigate the conditions that support spontaneous comparison and learning in 7- and 9-month-olds.  The third series will test how language influences relational learning- specifically, whether naming relations can improve learning, and whether naming objects can impede relational learning.  The fourth series of experiments will investigate the generalizability of these effects by testing a variety of abstract relations.  Computational modeling of the learning patterns found in our studies will provide complementary insights on these processes. Taken together, these studies will reveal information critical to understanding analogical processes and the origin and evolution of higher-order cognition.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our first major paper under this grant provides evidence that infants as young as 3 months of age are capable of learning either the same or different relation and recognizing that relation with a new set of objects. Further, they show continuity in the characteristics of relational learning across development; like older infants and children, they show less ability to detect the same or different relation if the objects that make up the relation have been made salient. These findings demonstrate that prelinguistic infants can use structural alignment processes to abstract these relations. However, this learning is fragile:  3-month-old infants failed to abstract the same-different relations when presented with six exemplars but succeeded with two exemplars. More broadly, these findings provide evidence that infants are able to learn relations prior to the advent of language; thus, analogical ability is not dependent on language experience. Further experiments reveal the role of language and other factors in facilitating and hindering detection of the relations in infants.

Our second major paper delves into the conditions under which 3-month-old infants can learn from a single example. While there is abundant evidence that abstract relations can be learned by comparing two or more examples, if comparison is key to this process then it should not be possible to learn an abstract relation from a single example, even if that example is shown repeatedly. However, if, as we suspect, infants with less mature visual attention and encoding processes show variable encoding, then they will perceive repetitions of one example as a series of similar but distinct examples. If so, this could produce an ideal situation for infants to be able to compare and abstract the relation. This leads to the counterintuitive prediction: 3-month-old infants might learn from a single exemplar, but older infants, who have more stable encoding processes, would not learn from a single exemplar (because they will perceive it as the same example repeated, just as would an adult). The results supported our prediction. These findings have important implications for human cognition by highlighting that it is critical to consider not only what a learner has objectively been presented, but also what they have encoded when evaluating theories of learning. Additionally, while the maturation of our perceptual processes improves our abilities in innumerable ways, this study shows how immature perception might allow learning in circumstances that would not favor learning in older populations. We recently completed additional data to make it a high-impact publication. The additional data added a variable motion condition using a similar procedure. We anticipated that this introduction to the procedure would reverse the results: the 3-month-olds will fail to learn from one exemplar (because the repetitions will differ too much from one another); but the older infants will compare across the varying repetitions and thereby succeed in deriving the relational abstraction. Unfortunately, the older infants failed to learn so we are repackaging the findings with a more tempered interpretation. 

Our most recent empirical paper focused on how labels influence performance in the relational learning task. We found, no evidence that relational labels help 12-month-olds, suggesting that more linguistic experience may be required before relational labels can be readily understood to aid performance.

We published two review papers on relational learning and development in the journal Current Opinions in Behavioral Sciences. These papers examined the ontological and phylogenic profiles of relational learning—how processes of relational learning vary across human development and across species. 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2023
Modified by: Susan J Hespos
